justification: “Before the interaction with the robots began, each participant was given two personality related questionnaires, namely, BFI and NARS,” and subsequent analyses regress role-assignment on “Agreeableness,” indicating this trait was taken from the BFI.
Role-assignment was predicted by “− 0.14 * Neuroticism,” and the text notes that Neuroticism scores came from the BFI administered to every participant.
The logistic regression for the detective role includes “−2.47 * Conscientiousness,” showing this construct was measured through the BFI questionnaire given at the start.
The BFI provides all five classic personality dimensions; the article states that the BFI was one of the “two personality related questionnaires” administered, covering traits such as Extraversion.
Because the administered BFI captures the full Big-Five—including Openness—the questionnaire served as the measure for this construct.
Participants completed “NARS” prior to interacting with the robots, and later analyses relate “negative emotions towards robots” (from NARS) to detective-role assignment.
After the interaction, participants filled in “a comparative Godspeed questionnaire … [whose] five scales” include Anthropomorphism, making this the instrument for that construct.
The same sentence lists Animacy as one of the five Godspeed scales used to evaluate the robots.
The measurement section specifies Likeability as one of the Godspeed scales administered to rate the robots.
The Godspeed questionnaire “consists of five scales … Perceived Intelligence” confirming this scale measured that construct.
Perceived Safety is named as one of the five sub-scales in the Godspeed questionnaire given to participants to assess their perception of the robots.
